newsitem.title: UK: UK debt to fall to 40% of GDP in 1998 - Heseltine.
newsitem.headline: UK debt to fall to 40% of GDP in 1998 - Heseltine.

text.p: Britain's national debt will fall next year to the government's target of 40 percent of national income, deputy Prime Minister Michael Heseltine said on Thursday.

"It has been the prime objective of this government to lower public expenditure," he told parliament. "In the next financial year we are set to meet our target of reducing public expenditure below 40 percent of GDP."
He noted that most economies on the European continent had "conspicuously higher" debt levels.
Heseltine repeated accusations made by the Conservative Party earlier this week that the opposition Labour Party has made 30 billion pounds worth of spending pledges.
"By our calculation, there has been 30 billion pounds of these pledges. Not one has been renounced," Heseltine said. "They never answer the question, where is the money coming from."
On Tuesday, when the Conservative claims were unveiled, Labour moved quickly to dismiss them as a "pack of lies."

Shadow Chancellor of the Exchequer Gordon Brown has promised to stick to Conservative spending plans for the first two years of a Labour government. He has also pledged not to raise income tax in the life of the next government.
